Organic Catalyst Market to Grow at a CAGR of 5.7% by 2033 - Leading Companies Include BASF SE, Solvay S.A., Evonik Industries, Merck KGaA, and Johnson Matthey
            11-08-2025 09:44 AM CET | 
IT, New Media & Software
Press release from: 
DataHorizzon Research
Organic Catalyst Market
According to a new study by DataHorizzon Research, the "Organic Catalyst Market" is projected to grow at a CAGR of 5.7% from 2025 to 2033, driven by the rising demand for sustainable and environmentally friendly catalytic solutions in the chemical, pharmaceutical, and energy industries. The growing emphasis on green chemistry, coupled with regulatory pressure to minimize toxic waste and reduce the use of heavy metal catalysts, is propelling the adoption of organic catalysts (organocatalysts) across a wide range of industrial processes. Furthermore, advancements in synthetic chemistry and process intensification are enhancing catalytic efficiency and selectivity, making organic catalysts a preferred alternative for future-ready chemical manufacturing.
Market Size & Insights

Talking to the Dead with AI: The Promise, the Illusion, and the Business Behind It
Talking to the Dead with AI: The Promise, the Illusion, and the Business Behind It
6 Min read
Divya Danu
 Published : Nov 08 2025, 02:11 PM IST

AI 'Deathbots' promise digital resurrection but raise deep moral questions (Representative photo)
Image Credit: Getty
A new study has explored the rise of 'deathbots', AI systems that simulate the voices and personalities of deceased. Researchers created digital doubles of themselves to test the tech and found it emotionally limited, and commercially driven.
Artificial Intelligence (AI) is now stepping into one of the most sensitive areas of human life, death and memory. A growing number of companies are developing 'deathbots', AI-powered chatbots that can mimic the voices, language, and personalities of people who have died. These systems promise to let loved ones 'speak' with the deceased, but they also raise serious questions about technology, emotion and ethics, 
reports
